newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek money rates hold, shorts ease in late trade.
newsitem.headline: Greek money rates hold, shorts ease in late trade.

text.p: Greek money and bond markets were calm in late dealing with rates holding morning levels as the sale of T-bills covered expiries but did not do as well as expected, dealers said.

"Rates have not changed much in late trade," said a state bank dealer. "I can say that shorts but for overnight funds have slipped a bit as the sale of T-bills seems to have exceeded expiries by just 10 to 15 percent, less than expected."
The state issued 12-month T-bills today that yield 11.50 percent, down 50 basis points from the previous issue.
"The lower yield seems to have adversely affect the issue although they still enjoy the tax free status," said a foreign bank dealer.
Greece is to levy a 7.5 percent tax on interest from government securities issued after January 1.
Bond traders said the market was quiet with light trading activity.
The mark was quoted at 157.15/25 drachmas from Monday's 157.100 fix, the dollar at 241.96/06 drachmas from 242.030 and the Ecu at 303.91/01 from 303.850 drachmas.
The National Bank of Greece, the domestic money market's biggest player, quoted the following late rates:
